functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

msg.content: Which planets in our solar system were discovered after 1700, and who discovered them?
Which planets in our solar system were discovered after 1700, and who discovered them?
Let me help break this down into a research question about planetary discoveries after 1700.

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions": "Please research and provide information about which planets in our solar system were discovered after the year 1700, including who discovered them and when. Focus only on confirmed planets (not dwarf planets like Pluto)."}

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Please research and provide information about which planets in our solar system were discovered after the year 1700, including who discovered them and when. Focus only on confirmed planets (not dwarf planets like Pluto).
I'll help you research this information about planet discoveries after 1700. Let me search for relevant details.

No page with that title exists. Try searching for one of these similar articles instead:
- Uranus
- Moons of Uranus
- Puck (moon)
- Miranda (moon)
- Discovery of Neptune
- Timeline of discovery of Solar System planets and their moons
- Oberon (moon)
- Uranus (mythology)
- Rings of Uranus
- Titania (moon)
msg.name: search

msg.content: Let me search for a more specific article that might contain this information.

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"query": "Timeline of discovery of Solar System planets and their moons"}

article_title: Timeline of discovery of Solar System planets and their moons

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Timeline of discovery of Solar System planets and their moons</title>
<fragment>

The timeline of discovery of Solar System planets and their natural satellites charts the progress of the discovery of new bodies over history. Each object is listed in chronological order of its discovery (multiple dates occur when the moments of imaging, observation, and publication differ), identified through its various designations (including temporary and permanent schemes), and the discoverer(s) listed.

</fragment>
<fragment>
11. **^** Blue, Jennifer (November 9, 2009). "Planet and Satellite Names and Discoverers". USGS. Retrieved January 13, 2010.
12. **^** "*De Saturni luna observatio nova* (1656)". *Departement Natuurkunde*. Universiteit Utrecht. Archived from the original on August 16, 2004. Retrieved May 11, 2005.
13. **^** Christiaan Huygens (1659). "Systema Saturnium". The Hague: Adriani Vlacq. p. 47 – via Smithsonian Institution Libraries.
14. **^** Cassini, Giovanni D.; *Découverte de deux nouvelles planètes autour de Saturne* Archived May 13, 2006, at the Wayback Machine, Sébastien Mabre-Cramoisy, Paris, 1673.  
Translated as "A Discovery of two *New Planets* about *Saturn,* made in the Royal Parisian Observatory by Signor *Cassini,* Fellow of both the Royal Societys, of *England* and *France;* English't out of French". *Philosophical Transactions*. **8**: 5178–5185. 1673. JSTOR 101334.

</fragment>
<fragment>
| **Moon** | ![](image) | Earth I
 | In the Copernican system, the Moon was considered to be no longer a planet but a natural satellite of the Earth, and was originally thought to be the only body in that system whose revolution was not centered on the Sun.
 |
| *Mercury* | ![](image) | *1st Planet* | Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn were identified by ancient Babylonian astronomers in the 2nd millennium BC.[7] They were correctly identified as orbiting the Sun by Aristarchus of Samos, and later in Nicolaus Copernicus' heliocentric system[8] (*De revolutionibus orbium coelestium*, 1543)
 |
| *Venus* | ![](image) | *2nd Planet* |
| *Mars* | ![](image) | *4th Planet* |
| *Jupiter* | ![](image) | *5th Planet* |
| *Saturn* | ![](image) | *6th Planet* |


## 17th century[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>
Thе history of discovering planets and moons


Template:Lists of Solar System objects


</fragment>

| **Callisto** | ![](image) | Jupiter IV

<fragment>
With the explosion of discoveries in the 21st century, new moons have once again started to be left unnamed even after their numbering, beginning with Jupiter LI and Jupiter LII in 2010.




## Key info[edit]


In the following tables, planetary satellites are indicated in bold type (e.g. **Moon**) while planets and dwarf planets, which directly circle the Sun, are in italic type (e.g. *Earth*). The Sun itself is indicated in roman type. The tables are sorted by publication/announcement date. Dates are annotated with the following symbols:



* *i:* for date of first imaging (photography, etc.);
* *o:* for date of first human visual observation, either through telescope or on photographic plate;
* *p:* for date of announcement or publication.


In a few cases, the date is uncertain and is then marked "(?)".


</fragment>

29. **^** Airy, George Biddell (November 13, 1846). "Account of some circumstances historically connected with the discovery of the Planet exterior to Uranus". *Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society*. **7** (9): 121–152.
30. **^** Galle, J. G. (November 13, 1846). "Account of the Discovery of the Planet of Le Verrier at Berlin". *Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society*. **7** (9): 153–157.
31. **^** Lassell, William (1846). "Discovery of supposed ring and satellite of Neptune". *Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society*. **7**: 157. Bibcode:1846MNRAS...7..157L.

Seven planets were placed in orbit around it in an order of increasing distance from the Earth, as established by the Greek Stoics: the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. This list included two objects, the Sun and the Moon, which are now not generally considered planets.

1. **^** At the time of Neptune's discovery, dwarf planet Ceres and asteroids Pallas, Juno, Vesta, and Astraea were counted as planets.

The discovery of Amalthea marks the first time the Roman numerals were not adjusted with the discovery of a new satellite; from then on they reflected order of discovery rather than distance from the parent planet.



## 20th century[edit]

<fragment>
It is not known precisely how many objects in the Solar System are dwarf planets; the nine objects listed in the third column are those agreed on by most astronomers, corresponding to a threshold of about 900 km diameter. There may be more; here, all objects with estimated diameter over 700 km are included as dwarf planet candidates, listed in the fourth column. In particular, Salacia and Varda each have a rather large moon, and current estimates for their densities still leave open the possibility that they are dwarf planets.



Designations
* Other designations are synonyms or periphrases sometimes encountered for the object.
* Permanent designations (of planetary satellites) are explained here.
* Temporary designations are explained here.


If a satellite is named, its name is bolded; if it is unnamed, but has a permanent designation, then its permanent designation is bolded; and if it has neither, then its temporary designation is bolded.



## Prehistorically discovered[edit]

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about the planets discovered after 1700 in our solar system. There were only two planets discovered after 1700:

1. Uranus
- Discovered by: William Herschel
- Discovery date: March 13, 1781 (first observation), officially announced on April 26, 1781
- Note: Herschel initially thought it was a comet when he first observed it

2. Neptune
- Discovered by: Johann Gottfried Galle and Urbain Le Verrier
- Discovery date: September 23, 1846 (first observation), officially announced on November 13, 1846
- Note: Neptune's discovery was particularly remarkable because its existence was mathematically predicted by Le Verrier before it was actually observed by Galle

All other planets in our solar system (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn) were known since ancient times, having been identified by Babylonian astronomers in the 2nd millennium BC. These planets were visible to the naked eye and had been observed and documented by various ancient civilizations.

It's worth noting that while Pluto was discovered in 1930 by Clyde Tombaugh, it is no longer classified as a planet, having been reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006, so it's not included in this list of confirmed planets.

I'll help you research this information about planet discoveries after 1700. Let me search for relevant details.


Let me search for a more specific article that might contain this information.

Based on the search results, I can provide information about the planets discovered after 1700 in our solar system. There were only two planets discovered after 1700:

1. Uranus
- Discovered by: William Herschel
- Discovery date: March 13, 1781 (first observation), officially announced on April 26, 1781
- Note: Herschel initially thought it was a comet when he first observed it

2. Neptune
- Discovered by: Johann Gottfried Galle and Urbain Le Verrier

msg.name: delegate

msg.content:
Based on the research, only two planets in our solar system were discovered after 1700:

1. Uranus was discovered by William Herschel on March 13, 1781. Interestingly, when Herschel first observed it, he initially thought it was a comet.

2. Neptune was discovered on September 23, 1846, through the combined work of Johann Gottfried Galle and Urbain Le Verrier. This discovery was particularly notable because Le Verrier had mathematically predicted Neptune's existence before it was actually observed by Galle.

All other planets in our solar system (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn) were known since ancient times and were visible to the naked eye, having been documented by Babylonian astronomers as far back as the 2nd millennium BC.

Based on the research, only two planets in our solar system were discovered after 1700:

1. Uranus was discovered by William Herschel on March 13, 1781. Interestingly, when Herschel first observed it, he initially thought it was a comet.

2. Neptune was discovered on September 23, 1846, through the combined work of Johann Gottfried Galle and Urbain Le Verrier. This discovery was particularly notable because Le Verrier had mathematically predicted Neptune's existence before it was actually observed by Galle.

All other planets in our solar system (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn) were known since ancient times and were visible to the naked eye, having been documented by Babylonian astronomers as far back as the 2nd millennium BC.
